International Tuition: $17,891.00

- Winter 2024: Closed for domestic and international students
- Spring 2024: Not Available for both domestic and international students

Context:
This advanced diploma program is focused on Building Automation and equips students with the technical skills required for installing, programming, adjusting, and maintaining building automation systems. Students will learn to collect data from sensors, actuators, and controllers and work with various building software platforms that interconnect different systems. The graduates of this program will have a diverse set of skills and abilities, including those needed for "green" careers.

The industry skills taught in the program include safety practices, HVAC/R processes, control loops and modes, working with blueprints and manufacturer's technical instructions, software usage, various BAS controls and systems, functions of network devices and protocols, and emerging green technologies.

Career options for graduates are available in various areas of the building industry. Some potential career paths include installation, maintenance, programming, and troubleshooting of HVAC/R and electrical systems using digital, analog, pneumatic, DCS, PLC, PAC, and SCADA controls and systems, as well as networking devices and protocols like Zigbee, WiFi, BAS/IP, and BACnet.

Emerging green technologies, such as solar, wind, and hydronic systems, are also covered in the program to prepare graduates for careers focused on energy efficiency, renewable energy, and sustainability.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2023/Electromechanical Engineering Technology – Building Automation Program T171 | George Brown College2023.txt

Context:
Extracted Information:

1. Career opportunities in the building automation industry include electronics companies, general contractors, communication and information systems companies, lighting suppliers and contractors, mechanical and electronic controller manufacturers, facilities management companies, automotive companies and suppliers, robotics and automation companies, and residential developers.
2. Required courses for the first semester include EMNG 1001 (Circuit Analysis), EMNG 1004 (Metrology), MENG 1002 (Engineering Drawing), MENG 1087 (Machining Fundamentals), MENG 1088 (Occupational Health and Safety), GSSC 1027 (Personal Finance), MATH 1160 (Mathematics for Engineering Technology 1), COMM 2000 (Communicating Across Contexts).
3. Required courses for the second semester include EMNG 1003 (Engineering Physics), EMNG 1012 (Introduction to Mechanical CAD), EMNG 1013 (Electronic Devices), EMNG 1015 (Motors & Controls), EMNG 1016 (Electro-Pneumatics), MATH 1171 (Mathematics for Engineering Technology 2), GSSC 1100 (Small Business Plan and Operation).
4. Required courses for the third semester include EMNG 2001 (Introduction to PLC Systems), EMNG 2004 (Digital Electronics), EMNG 2006 (Operations Management and Quality Control), EMNG 2020 (Sensors & Instrumentation), EMNG 2021 (Automation Software Development), EMNG 3020 (Blueprint Reading for Buildings), GNED (General Education Elective).
5. Required courses for the fourth semester include EMNG 2022 (Measurement and Final Control Elements), EMNG 2024 (Internet of Things for Homes and Buildings), EMNG 2025 (Electrical Techniques), MENG 2046 (Sustainable Energy Technologies), MENG 3006 (Thermodynamics), GNED (General Education Elective).
6. Required courses for the fifth semester include EMNG 2026 (Applied Project 1), EMNG 3002 (Building Science Fundamentals), EMNG 3016 (Fundamentals of HVAC/R Systems), EMNG 3004 (Building Networks and Protocols), EMNG 3006 (Alarm and Video Systems), EMNG 3015 (Building Control Systems).
7. Required courses for the sixth semester include GNED (General Education Elective). No specific course code was provided in the text.
8. General education electives are required in various semesters as marked by the "GNED" code.

Context:
The text provides information about various courses offered in the EMNG (Electromechanical Engineering) program at the college. Here are the codes and names of those courses:

1. EMNG 3015 - Building Control Systems
2. EMNG 2040 - Workplace Preparedness and Technical Writing
3. EMNG 3011 - Building Management and Commissioning
4. EMNG 3013 - Building Sub-Systems and Integration
5. EMNG 3018 - Applied Project 2
6. EMNG 3019 - Building Operations and Management
7. EMNG 3021 - Connected Homes

The text also mentions that students may be required to take COMM 1000 (Introduction to College Communication) before progressing to COMM 2000, but this course does not count towards graduation requirements and students will be charged for it. There is a link provided for more information: Assessment Centre

Furthermore, the text lists several program learning outcomes that EMNG graduates are expected to demonstrate upon completion of their degree. These include:

1. Fabricating and building electrical, electronic, and mechanical components and assemblies
2. Analyzing, interpreting, and producing technical drawings and documents
3. Troubleshooting techniques and equipment for electromechanical systems
4. Modifying, maintaining, and repairing various components and systems
5. Designing and analyzing mechanical components, processes, and systems
6. Installing and troubleshooting computer hardware and programming
7. Analyzing, programming, installing, integrating, and diagnosing automated systems
8. Establishing and maintaining inventory, records, and documentation systems
9. Selecting and purchasing electromechanical equipment that meets job requirements and functional specifications
10. Specifying, coordinating, and applying quality-control and quality-assurance programs and procedures
11. Working in compliance with relevant industry standards, laws, regulations, codes, policies, and procedures
12. Developing strategies for ongoing personal and professional development to enhance work performance and remain current in the field.

Context:
The text provides information about a program offered at George Brown College, specifically an electromechanical engineering program. Here are some key factual information extracted from the text:

- The program is designed for professional development and staying current in the field, including working as an individual and team member to complete tasks and projects.
- Students will design and analyze electromechanical systems using fluid mechanics principles.
- There are contributions to project management through planning, implementation, and evaluation of projects, as well as monitoring resources, timelines, and expenditures.
- Tuition and fees differ for domestic and international students, with listed amounts for the first two semesters starting in Fall 2022 and Fall 2023, respectively. Additional costs include safety shoes and glasses.
- The program is approved for OSAP funding for eligible applicants.
- Admission requirements include an Ontario Secondary School Diploma or equivalent, grade 12 English (C or U), and grade 11 Math (M or U) or grade 12 (C or U). Mature students may take the Admissions Assessment for English and math or upgrade to achieve required credits.
- The information in the text is subject to change without notice, and students are responsible for verifying George Brown College fee requirements.

Context: Applicants are required to apply through Ontario Colleges for domestic students, and through the George Brown College Online Application System for international students. The contact information for the School of Mechanical Engineering Technologies is 416-415-5000, ext. 4365 with email engineeringtech@georgebrown.ca, located in room D305. For more information about George Brown College, applicants can contact the Contact Centre at 416-415-2000 (TTY 1-877-515-5559) or long distance 1-800-265-2002. International students can also contact international recruitment representatives by booking a virtual meeting or submitting an inquiry on the International Contact Us page. Applicants can sign up for information sessions and explore related programs such as Electromechanical Engineering Technician (T146), Mechanical Engineering Technology – Design (T121), and Electrical Techniques (T167). Interested individuals can also book a campus tour and sign up to receive tailored resources to make their application process easier.
